Award.AwardTitle: SCC-Planning: Towards Smart and Accessible Transportation Hub - Research Capacity Building and Community Engagement

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This SCC-Planning project will be design a human-centered service system, using the existing cyber infrastructure of a transportation hub. Users will be assisted by an "app" for navigating complicated buildings and urban spaces. With this app, the visually impaired, whose numbers exceed 6 million individuals today, will find using public transportation services more convenient and efficient. There are significant hurdles to be overcome to realize this design, called the Smart and Accessible Transportation Hub (SAT-Hub), which will extend an individual's mobility, offer greater freedom of movement, and open new possibilities for daily living and community engagement. In addition, the SAT-Hub will provide unique, interdisciplinary training opportunities for students, including under-represented populations in STEM at CUNY City College, CUNY Borough of Manhattan Community College and Rutgers.

The planning for the SAT-Hub will bring together several technical areas: smart infrastructures and sensing and computing with transportation planning and accessibility and mobility. The project has three main objectives: (1) design a smart transportation hub framework for experimenting, debugging, and refining the smart service, (2) strengthen partnerships with community stakeholders by exploring the unique needs of their user communities through regular community engagement, and (3) identify cross-disciplinary, integrative research themes to enable the successful deployment of a solution. The City University of New York and Rutgers University will work to meet these objectives with our partners from local government in NY and in NJ, the regional transit agencies, and the service institutions for underserved users.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The CUNY-Rutgers joint academic team, in close collaboration with Lighthouse Guild and three sectors of community partners representing transportation agencies, service institutions and local government agencies , aims to bring Smart and Accessible Transportation Hub (SAT-Hub) service to all, especially to people with disabilities. We leverage several transportation facilities at the heart of New York City and the State of New Jersey as testbeds for the proposed study. Our team combines interdisciplinary background and collective synergies in urban systems, infrastructure engineering, transportation planning and travel behavior analysis, sensing, computing and data analytics, accessibility considering perceptual & cognitive human factors, and paratransit services.

The planning for the SAT-Hub has three main goals: (1) Design a smart transportation hub framework for experimenting, debugging, and refining the smart service; (2) Strengthen partnerships with community stakeholders by exploring the unique needs of their user communities through regular community engagement; and (3) Identify cross-disciplinary, integrative research themes to enable the successful deployment of a solution.

Travelers with disabilities often have lower tolerance to failure than normal travelers do, perhaps due to their increased perceived danger and the larger cognitive burden when travelling. To address these challenges, we propose an integrated and human-centered cyber-physical infrastructure framework that can effectively and efficiently transform existing transportation hubs into smart facilities that are capable of providing more efficient location-awareness and personalized navigation services (e.g. finding terminals, improving travel experience, obtaining security alerts) to the traveling public. Although we initially aim to develop accessibility for underserved populations including those with mobility/hearing/visual impairment, Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), or those simply navigation challenge, our goal is to develop universally accessible technology.

We leverage several transportation facilities in the heart of New York City and throughout the State of New Jersey as testbeds for the proposed study thus ensuring the relevance of the research and the smooth transition of the developed SAT-Hub to real world applications with significant societal impacts. During the period of research, we have interacted with people with  a number of agencies - including NYC Port Authority, MTA, NJ Transit in both NYC and NJ, and NJ Passaic County for cyber infrastructure testbed selections. Our various partners operating the sites all have great need to make their transportation hubs smarter and more accessible for people with disabilities living in and coming to the greater New York City area.

As the name of our proposed work indicated - Smart and Accessible Transportation Hub, the novelty of the work in the integration of three major elements: intelligence, accessibility, and transportation. Specifically, the intellectual merit of the work lies in at least three aspects:

(1) The innovative combination of indoor crowd/traffic analysis and 3D facility information for assisting localization and path planning. Integration of crowd dynamic information with 3D static information is the first-of-its-kind work and key to providing customized paths for people with travel and mobility challenges.

(2) The focus of the work is the use of indoor crowd traffic analysis to better serve passengers in navigating through or away from crowds. There are many working on crowd and traffic analysis, but few of them are focused on assisting people with disabilities, especially in indoor environments.

(3) The key feature of the project is smart transportation with accessibility, by considering the walkability of the paths and the crowd traffic information, which are crucial for people who are blind or with ASD.

Even within the SCC planning with small user group studies, demo system development, and workshops, we have had our students fully involved, including those major activities such as performing literature reviews, participating in site visits, working on user group studies, presenting their research projects during the workshops using posters, and preparing and analyzing the workshop evaluation forms. In this way, the students have been involved in the full cycle of problem identification, cross-border collaborations, system development, and user evaluation.
